The squalor of black Bates. Trash. Lowriders. Graffiti. Vacant lots. Boarded-up buildings. Sleazy bars. The broken beer bottles in that street alone pick up the ligh of dawn. Other than that, sleeping cats and deep shadows. The people making love are getting it together. QUICKENIN BREATHING. An urgency.

in the three-room, clapboard house with a For Sale sign i front. The paint is peeling, some windows broken, the curtains limp, the whole house sags to the north, but it' no worse than all the other houses in the area. The BREATHING is PUNCTUATED with LITTLE GASPS OF PLEASURE

The interior walls have been removed, except for the bath room it is one large space, oddly livable and nice, amid poverty. The furniture is Goodwill reject. Fair Housing picket sign. Law books. A jockstrap. Monet's water lilies tacked to the stained wallpaper. An old typewriter Stacks of yellow paper, full of typing and legal pads full of handwriting. Bowl:of dried Chinese vegetables, different gauge pasta and dried flowers. A sink corroded through, with a wrench for a faucet and a bucket to catch the leaks. An Air Force exercise chart. A flourishing philodendron. The BREATHING is FASTER. WHIMPERS and SIGHS and FANFARE.
They fall apart, happy. JACK is a thin man with a beard. ANGELA is an NYU law school graduate and a vivid beauty. (CONTINUED)
How do you feel?
Saved. She laughs, snuggles closer.
Your beard is manifestation of a death wish, Jack, did you know that?
Sheeit.
Bates considers beards a brand of communism.
Why do you carry on like it was a ten, if it wasn't ten?
Bates owns the town. It's asking for failure. Up on his elbow, irritated.
Now wait a second. I don't have to suck up to that anybody. I've got a publisher. She caresses his beard, deaf.
Shave it off. Take some menial job. You haven't worked in so long you've forgotten how.
Writing a book isn't working?
It would be healthy. He looks at her owlishly.
I'm unhealthy? (CONTINUED)
There's a direct correlation between unemployment and sexual malfunctioning.
Was it a nine?
We used up the publishers' advance six months ago.
Eight?
We've got to come up with two grand by the end of the month or we lose the house, Jack. Jack remembers suddenly -- goes rigid -- grabs his watch.
Oh, Jesus. I'm having breakfast with the Bank in twenty minutes. Leaps out of bed, stops mid air:
(continuing) Seven?
(grins, grudgingly) And a half. He leaps back on top of her.
You are so full of bullshit, woman...
He looks at her, vibrant with admiration, stunned at his good luck.
Let's get married. She hugs him, abruptly as soft as she was fierce. (CONTINUED)
What're you gonna tell the Bank?
(stroking her hair, comforting her) Couple of jokes. It'll be all right. Bankers have a sense of humor too. (looks into her eyes) If I get an extension of credit, can we get married? Long look.
Yep. He hoots with triumph, sweeps her into his arms.

Wide, bleak and untended, full of dust and broken promise Beat-up pickups. Old cars on blocks in front yards. Though it is still early, there are people leaning on por rails, on cars, hanging out, going nowhere. Jack eases hi old ten speed out of the house. CREDITS.

swings up onto his bike and starts down the street, avoid the potholes and glass and stray dogs. The kids and neighbors wave greetings. He waves back, settling a green backpack on his shoulders, riding on, without hands. Whistling.

Mostly boarded up empty store fronts. Many businesses wit "Bates" in the title. The newspaper building, the Dixie Daily (A Division of Bates Enterprises), is still in operation, on the main square. The square itself sports a larger than life statue of Bates in stone. Jack breezes by on his bike, whistling, tosses the statue the finger.  10 ‘all 12 13

Jack rides his bike up a gangplank, hops off. La Noisette Rose is a restaurant on a paddle wheeler, on the Mississippi. Open 24 Hours. Chicken Fried Steak our Specialty! CREDITS END.

An air of superiority. Views of refineries and muddy rive out the windows. Pink tableclothes, waiters in pink jackets. A small bowl of pink walnuts on each table. Most of the customers are middle-aged, florid-faced men in business suits breakfasting with young blondes in form fitting jeans, satin blouses with tooled cowboy boots and the Farah Fawcett hairdos. Jack Brown is finishing breakfast with a sour looking BANKER in a three-piece pin striped suit. There is an awkward silence. Jack sets down his coffee cup with a clatter.
Sorry. (smiles ingratiatingly) Know why Dolly Parton's feet are so small?

Heard about the Polish mosquito? (CONTINUED)

(tight rage) Jack, you need a paying job by the end of the week. Or we'll repossess everything you own, starting with your goddam typewriter. CHOP. The pitcher of cream jumps off the table into the Banker's lap. He stands, white liquid spread over his pants front.

Just send the bill to the house. The Waiter comes with the check on a little tray. Jack slips his credit card into the tray. The Waiter starts away. The Banker tackles him, snatches the credit card back.
You can't use this.
The bank won't cash my check.

(sotto voce) They don't know that here.
But the bank will have to honor this.
Exactly.

But I just told you. We aren't extending your credit unless you get a job. (digs for his wallet) I'll pay. Here. How much is it? The Banker takes the bill off the tray, red-faced with anger. The Waiter sticks a toothpick in his teeth and eyeballs the ceiling. Jack takes the bill back.
I can't allow you to do that. I invited you. You're my guest. I -- The Banker grabs it back, Jack grabs it back, knocks over the whole table.

Petroleum Engineer, Computer Programmer, Accountant, etc. And at the very bottom: Cleaning Woman (Part time).

Elegant people coming and going through the polished bron and glass revolving doors. Jack swings off his bike, begins to lock it to the Loadin Zone standard in front of the front door. Next to a parked Chrysler limousine. FANCY BATES, a very chic, very voluptuous creature of about twenty-five, sweeps out of the building, wearing a full length mink coat, heads for the limo. Behind her, wringing his hands is GEFFRAN, a balding, blue-suite nervous man. Behind him, BARKLEY, the chauffeur. Jack grins, moves his bike out of her way, opens the door of the car for her. She smiles at him regally.
Why, I do thank you so very much.
My pleasure, foxy lady. Barkley shuts the door with care.
Geffran mops his forehead, glancing sideways at Jack and his lascivious grin.
Not for you, pal.
It's a free country.
That's Fancy Bates.
His daughter?
Wife. Numero three. (CONTINUED)
No shit. Think she's ready for the black experience? Geffran winces. Laughing, Jack swings in the door.

Poster for the Bates Credit Union, sign up sheets for baseball teams. This is the employment office for Bates Enterprises. A couple of ancient black women are waiting. A couple of computer programmers. One engineer. The tweedy SECRETARY, Wellsley, looks disapprovingly at Jack who is sitting with the women, his bookbag between his knees. He smiles back at her. The Secretary looks at her list.
Miss Jackie Brown. Jack gets up, smiles at the Secretary, heads for the door
(continuing) Wait. Not you. We need a part- time woman.
(lisping) I can be a part-time woman. Wiggles into the office before she can stop him.
SIDNEY MOREHOUSE, the soul of propriety, is looking over the resume and clippings and articles in Jack's bookbag.
You're what I would call over qualified, Mr. Brown. What we want is a woman for three hours a night to clean around the window displays. You're a journalist.
The Dixie Daily pocens t hire blacks. LF (CONTINUED)
Is this a protest or something?
No, sir. I need the job. Morehouse shakes his head, begins to put the articles bac in the bag.
I'm sorry.
I can do anything a woman can do. Almost.
No. The answer's no. No now, no tomorrow. No next week. No next year.
What I like about this outfit is its open mindedness.

I know what Mr. Bates wants. To be crude, Aunt Jemima. You look nothing like Aunt Jemima. You look like trouble. What Mr. Bates does not want is trouble. Clippings and awards back in the bookbag. Hands it back to Jack, smiles.
-(continuing) Thank you for coming in. Miss Wellsley will give you a parking validation.
My girl friend's trouble, Mr. Morehouse, not me.
Your girl friend? What're you talking about?
She's the local legal staff +. the Southern Poverty Law enter.
(CONT INUED)

Is that meant to be amusing?
It's meant as a threat.
On what grounds could she possibly sue? .
It's illegal to hire a woman if a more competent man is available for the job.
More competent in whose opinion?
(yells) I'm not more competent than those deadbeat broads? Shall we have a carry a bucket of water up the escalator race? With all of them together? wipes his forehead with a large handkerchief.
It's a terrible job, Mr. Brown, if truth be told, you wouldn't like it, you have to come in at noon on Tuesdays and Fridays to serve staff luncheons --
I worked my way through college waiting tables.
As well as report at six p.m, every night of the week for three hours. The compensation is below --
I'll take it. (CONTINUED)
That bad out there?
Worse. Morehouse plays his last card.
How attached are you to that beard?
Am I gonna vacuum with my beard? Come on, man, that shit went out with the sixties. Morehouse smiles, relieved, triumphant.
We're all part of Mr. Bates' family here. In his family none of us wears. beards.
Reacting, digging in internally.

A clean-shaven Jack slides in the door. The kitchen is bustling with preparations for an elaborate luncheon for forty people. There are a dozen Aunt Jemima types in black uniforms, trimmed with white, the traditional white aprons and lace trimmed caps. RUBY DEE, an immense capabl black, turns with salad tongs and a scowl to Jack.
Whoever you want, she's busy. Come on back about three.
I'm looking for Ruby Dee.
That's me. What about?
I'm the new cleaning lady. (CONTINUED)
Christ Almighty, Morehouse flipped his lid.
He took pity on me, Mama, don't knock the dude.
(grins) Well, you sure gonna look weird in the uniform.

A long table set for a formal meal, complete with extra wine glasses, salad plates, butter plates, cold soup already at each of the forty places. There are forty executives, mostly men, in three piece Brooks Brothers suits and ties and conservative haircuts. The head accountant, Mr. Geffran, comes in from the hallw
(announcing) Mr. Bates is on his way. As a body, the executives move toward the table, talking in modulated, civilized tones. The waitresses come in, with serving dishes. Morehouse comes in.
He's on the phone to London, five minutes. As a body they move away from the table. Ruby Dee comes in from.the kitchen.
He's off the phone. Sit, kids. Like a wave to the tables.
as Geffran and Morehouse sit together. (CONTINUED)
Anything interesting going on in personnel?
Not really. In accounting?

Our move in Soybeans woke up the Justice Department. Cornering the market. (wipes his hands on his napkin) What's Bates supposed to do with his money? Whatever he buys he corners the market -- Spotting Jack, Morehouse chokes on his soup. Geffran slap him on the back.

Midway in the line of waitresses carrying serving dishes, Jack," in the waitress uniform: the black dress, the whit apron, the trimmed cap. He is carrying a silver dish full of bread, wrapped in a linen napkin. A crystal bowl of butter balls on ice.

As the women circulate, serving butter, salad, pouring ic water, wine, etc., no one but Morehouse notices Jack. After all, he's black and wearing a uniform. Morehouse glances frantically around the table. Two as Jack leans over Morehouse's left shoulder, unwrapping the bread.
Bread, Mr. Morehouse?
Get out of here, hurry, go, get some pants on, Mr. Brown, before Mr. Bates comes in. (CONT INUED)

Butter? Morehouse loosens his tie, mops his forehead with his napkin. Jack grins, circles the head of the table, pulling the head chair back, cutting in between to pass the bread to the other side of the table.

BATES comes in. Bates is Southern tradition, a good old boy with a wide stance, a ready smile and lethal eyes. He wears Brooks Brothers exclusively. Even his underwear is Brooks Brothers. Talk trails off. Everyone smiles toward the end of the table. The waitresses move toward his end, ready to serve him.
Good. Good. Time is money. Ruby Dee comes out of the kitchen before he gets to his chair.
Mr. Bates. Phone.
No calls.
It's your son.
(smiles, heads for kitchen) Oh. (to others) Excuse me.

picks up the hall extension in the kitchen. BATES © Eric? How was the flight? I'm real glad you're here, son, we're going to have a real good week together. (smiles) Anything you want. Absolutely.  29 30 31 32 33 16.
Bates strides over to the head chair, sits, pulls the table to him.
as the table slides past them, maybe three feet. They look at it, then at each other, then at Bates, then try to sort it out without objecting.
Impervious to the chaos he's created, he begins to eat.
lined up behind him, serving him, one after another.
trying to sort out the plates. Passing them back and forth, collecting the ones on his arm that no one claims. And the glasses. And the forks. And the ashtrays.

Here. I think this one's yours. It isn't? Sir, did you have a blueberry muffin? Whose blueberry muffin is this? What kind of salad dressing did you have? Here. Isn't that yours? I think so. Well just take it, nobody's got any diseases. How about this one for you? Does this look like your fork? Working his way down the table, collecting more and more plates that people won't claim, can't find the correct person for, until O'BRIEN at the end, who is eating in his lap.
Like the soup?
Very much.
Want a card table? (CONTINUED)
If it wouldn't be too much trouble.
Not at all.
Thank you, Miss. Jack heads for the kitchen door. Bates points at him,
You. Jack looks behind himself, no one. Then approaches Bates.
Me?
Who are you?
Your new cleaning woman, Mr. Bates. Bates nods.
Name?
Brown. Jack Brown.
The women I employ, Mr. Brown, are required to wear hose or shave their legs. Do you have three dollars for a pair of hose?
Not on me, but --
Then shave.
My legs?
Yes. (CONTINUED)
Now?
(smiles) Right now.

Still in his waitress uniform, one foot propped on the sink, Jack is trying to lather up the hair on his leg with the soap from the dispenser. Muttering. Then win- cing as he pulls the disposable razor through the mess. Other men using the facilities look at him strangely, then give him wide berth. Morehouse comes in.
Brown? Good God. What're you doing?
Shaving.
Your beard, man, all I meant was your beard.

(rinsing the razor) In the Bates family, we all shave our legs. Didn't you know? He told me himself. Smiles, exits. Morehouse looks after him a moment , Then picks up the razor, props his foot on the sink, slides up his pants. The door opens, Jack is there.
Schmuck! Vanishes, laughing.
In one of the boarded up office buildings, a store front remains open. (CONTINUED)

There are two black intellectuals, one man and one woman, each behind desks, on telephones. At the very back, Angela at her desk which is piled with papers, also on the phone. There are bookshelves full of lawbooks be- hind her. Around the walls posters celebrating the Klanwatch's activities. Jack is sitting in the chair across from Angela, his feet up on the desk, pissed.

(into phone, shrill) Seventy dollars? It's not possible! What're you lining them with, spun gold? (listens, gathers herself in hand) Of course do them, you goddam thief. I need brakes. And by five. (pleading) Five thirty. Yeah, okay. Hangs up, takes a breath to steady herself, grins at Jack
(continuing) I like your chin.
(pulling up his | pant leg) Wait'll you see my calves. She comes around her desk, plops into his lap, laughing.
You got a job. That's what's important. That's what's terrific.
It doesn't embarrass you to be living with a cleaning woman?
I think it's hysterical.
I think I'm gonna quit. (CONTINUED)
We need money, Jack. I don't care if you pump gas or push a broom or teach school, but do something, something with a paycheck.
I'm a journalist, goddammit, the only thing I'm comfortable doing is writing!
You don't wanna get married? He stares at her. Grins. They kiss.

The Chrysler limousine arrives. A small boy emerges. Starts for the front door. Sees the crowd by the window, walks over. He is wearing a military school uniform. ERIC BATES, nine-years-old, thin, self-assured and arrogant.

Jack is running the vacuum cleaner around the lingerie exhibit, four mannequins in bras and teddies and bikinis in a bathroom set. By accident, he knocks against a mannequin with the vacuum cleaner hose. She topples over, crashing into the others, they fall like a house of cards, one smashing her hand on the vanity table.
A fascinated crowd.

Jack has set two mannequins upright but in lifting #3 he knocks them over again. Looks, pained, at the mess around him, spots the broken hand. Picks it up. In doing so the vacuum cleaner cord becomes entangled, he ends on his ass.  40 ‘4L 42 43 44 45 46 21.
Some laugh. Some applaud. Some pull their children away. Barkely and Eric have gone.
The chrome and glass displays of expensive things are cold and forbidding in the darkness of the cold store. Eric comes in, followed by a phalanx of blue-suited managers.
follow, muttering to each other.
Why do I have to stay for this? I'm accounting. Is he going to exceed his credit limit?
It's always the toy department. I wish he'd grow up. I wish he'd get interested in stereos.
Eric stops. The men pile up behind him. The boy watches as Jack, unaware of his audience, tries to unscrew another mannequin's hand, with no success.
Give me a hand you tight-assed broad.
smiles. The Managers are in a quandary as to what to do.
gives up, picks up the broken hand, leaves her.

Jack finds himself in the display of life-sized stuffed figures of superheros from the movies. He knocks Batman over by accident. Picks him up.
Sorry, Bat. Pats him on the shoulder. The Batman collapses again. Jack tucks the mannequins hand into his back pocket, sets up the Batman again.
(continuing) On your feet, klutz. Bat collapses again. Jack lets out a sigh -- props him against Wonder Woman -- they nearly tip over -- he drags Superman into a sort of tri-pod arrangement.
(continuing; to Wonder Woman) Live it up, darling.
in the shadows turns to the blue-suited men behind him.
That. The toy department manager comes forward, adjusting his tie, smiling.
The Batman?
No. (points) Him. (CONTINUED)
Superman?
The black man.
whirls around in astonishment.
Alarm and consternation.
O'Brien, the toy manager, is about to cry.
The black man.
Yes.
He's not a toy.
I don't care.
He's one of our cleaning people, Eric.
I want him.
He's not for sale.
Why not?
Because he's... a person.
Daddy said anything I wanted. Anything in the store. (CONTINUED)
You can't buy a human being, Eric.
Why not?
Because you can't! The boy fixes him with a look. O'Brien finally crumbles.
who watches as O'Brien adjusts his tie, hikes up his pant swallows and with tangible reluctance walks the distance to Jack, hand extended, jovial smile in place.
Tim O'Brien. Toys.
(shakes the hand) Jack Brown. Windows.
The, uh, boy over there?
Yes?
He's uh, the son of our, uh --
Boss.
Right!
I can see a resemblance.
He, uh, would like to take you home with him.
What?
Just for a week. (CONTINUED)
Jack looks at him sideways, then at the boy, then at the manager.
Is he sick?
No.
Nuts?
No.
Then what are we talking about?
He's used to, uh, getting his own way.
Are you serious?
Very.
You want me to go with him?
If you wouldn't mind.
Well, I would.
I don’t want him throwing a tantrum in my department, please, Mr. Brown.
I don't give a damn where he throws his tantrum. The answer's no. O'Brien grabs him as he heads away, offers him a fifty dollar bill. Jack glares at him.
(continuing) I'm not for sale, man. (CONTINUED)
O'Brien palms him another fifty.
(continuing) I mean it. We sorted that out in the Civil War. O'Brien thumbs out four more fifties, slowly, then tucks them into Jack's pocket.
as O'Brien propels Jack over to the child.
The gentleman will be delighted, Eric. His name is Jack Brown. Jack, this is Master Bates. Jack does a take, no one else seems to have heard. He extends his hand. Eric ignores it.
I'll call him nigger.
And I'll call you prick. Stunned silence. Then the child smiles.
Wrap him up.
What?! Eric's eyes flick dangerously toward the toy manager. He loosens his tie, sighs, takes Jack aside again. Two Jack is boiling. O'Brien soothing.
We'll make you very comfortable. Foam. A chair. A roomy box --
Goddammit! (CONTINUED)

(tucks another $50 into Jack's pocket) Mr. Brown, my house is mortgaged, twice, my wife's parents live with us. Her father is on dialysis, and even with Medicare, lemme tell you, it's a helluva struggle. One word from the boy and I'll lose my job. Jack glares at the child a moment.
He needs a good whipping.
(another $50 into Jack's pocket) I really don't care what you do to him once you get there. Jack looks at him.
as a large elegant Bates Department Store van sweeps unde the flowing cottonwoods along the drive up to the two- story house.

The boy is sitting at the end of a long formal table, eating alone, except for a hatchet-faced MADEMOISELLE at his side, doing needlepoint. He's eating his peas one by one. He has not touched his liver. Or his sweet potatoes. He is leaning on his elbow, profoundly bored.

(in French) Elbows off the table. (nothing; in French) Sit up, Eric. (mothing; in French) Our stomachs will digest our food better if we eat some vegetable, some meat and some starch, in that order. Not all the vegetable at one time -- (CONTINUED)
I hate liver.
(in French) I understand nothing but French.

I hate French. With a drink in his hand, Bates comes in as Mademoiselle is about to blow her stack. She settles quickly. Bates sits next to Eric, whiskey at hand. Eric plays with the peas on his plate.
So, how are you?
Okay.
How's school?
Okay.
Who are your friends?
Dunno.
What classes do you enjoy?
Dunno.
How're your grades?
Okay.
Don't they teach you to look a man in the eye when you talk to him?
Yup.
Then why don't you? (CONTINUED)
Because you're not my Commander in Chief. Barkley puts his head in the door.
Excuse me. Eric, your present has arrived. Eric leaps to his feet, knocking over his chair, running toward the door. Mademoiselle springs to her feet, outraged.
(in French) Not until you eat your liver!
(overlapping) Eric! Eric ignores them both, flies out of the room. Bates sighs, downs his drink,

The boy bursts in the door. It is a magnificent room, large and full of toys, a fort built of huge blocks of styrofoam, covered in bright-covered cloth and velcro, an electric train systems, a space shuttle device that hangs in the air, a Superman hang glider suspended from the ceiling, an air hockey game, slot machines, pinball machines, computers, typewriters. And in the middle of this, a wooden packing crate, dwarfed by the size and opulence of the room. Eric walks over to the box, touches it, a smile of triump on his face. Mademoiselle appears in the doorway.
(in French) Eric. Come and finish your dinner. Right now.
Get me a hammer.
¢in French) First you will finish -- (CONTINUED)
No.
(in French) I'll tell your father.
Get me a hammer!
(in French) If you don't come finish your dinner right now you won't open that till tomorrow.
Are you crazy! Mademoiselle jumps a foot. Bates appears in the doorway.
Eric --
She won't help me open my present. She won't get me a hammer.
He hasn't touched his liver.
Help! Bates blinks, approaches.
What's this? Eric avoids his father's eyes.
You said I could have anything in the store.
Would someone let me out of here! Eric finally meets his father's eyes. Silence.
“¢ (to Mademoiselle) 5 Get a hammer. (CONTINUED)
She swallows her anger and rushes out. Bates touches the box.
(louder) Can you hear me in there?
Yes, sir.
Who are you?
The new part-time cleaning lady, sir. At the store. Jack Brown.
How did this happen?
I was doing my job, minding my business. Your son came along and asked them to wrap me up. Which they did. Bates paces, avoiding the boy's eyes, then whirls on him furious.
I hope you have an explanation of this.
You said anything in the store. He was in the store.
Sir --
She's just coming with the hammer. Mademoiselle returns with the hammer, hands it to Bates.

(taking the hammer) I get to open it. It's my present. He pries t!-2 néi?s’out, folds the top back with a SCREECHING OF NAILS. Jack stands stiffly, excelsior dripping from his hair, styrofoam clinging to his clothes (CONTINUED)
He impales the boy with a look, puts his hands on the edg of the box and jumps out, angry, with himself mostly.
What the hell, for another couple of bucks I'd probably do it naked. Heads for door.
Sir --
Naked, sir.
I mean come here a minute.
Forget it. Continues toward the door. Eric lobs a FIRECRACKER. It EXPLODES in front of Jack, who falls flat on his face. The boy, to his side, laughing. — ERIC We can have lots of fun, you and me.
I'll pay you on an hourly basis.
I'd forgotten. The one thing I hate worse than white people is rich white people. Heads for the door again.
as Jack strides down the hall, Bates beside him.
What sort of full-time position would you be interested in, Mr. Brown?
"Slave' too cras7* —— (CONTINUED)
I'm serious. Jack stops in the hall, faces the whale of a man.

I am, too. I'm a newspaperman, Mr. Bates. I been without a job in this town for a year because you own the paper and you don't hire blacks. Unless they do windows. And wait tables. And kiss ass. (beat, grins) I just tried it. I don't like it. - Heads down the hall again. Bates beside him.
I only have him for a week, every year.
Get a better lawyer. You shouldn't have to have him that much.
I love him, Mr. Brown.
I don't care!
He wants you to stay.
He doesn't. He wants to see if you can make me stay. It's a power play. Manipulative little bastard.
If you were less hysterical, Mr. Brown, you might suggest that I pay you for the week, what I pay my reporters. A thousand dollars.
(stunned) For babysitting? (CONTINUED)
Bates smiles, lethal. Jack looks down the hall at the kid, in exactly the same position as his father. Then bac at the man.
(continuing; stunned) Is it inherited or contagious?
(smiles) Come down to my office.

Freestanding models of the Bates stores with a profit/los chart attached to each. Posters charting the demographics of the area: buying power per capita per county, driving habits, gas prices, advertising dollars, etc. On the wall facing Bates' desk, a blowup of the region with golden TV towers indicating each of his cable networks and golden threads connecting them to the central and tallest tower in Bates. On the wall behind the desk, life-sized portrai of Fancy as the Naked Raja, but with a string Bikini-bott in the shape of a heart over the critical area. Bates has his confederate flag standing discreetly in front of the boobs. Bates sinks into his leather chair, waves at Jack to take the chair across from him.
